project.name: RoboHydra public API
project.description: Public RoboHydra functions and classes available to plugins

RoboHydra.name: RoboHydra
RoboHydra.description:
Dispatches the incoming requests. Normally there is only one of
this per server, but there can be several if summoners are
used.

params.name: extraVars
params.description:
An optional object with the extra
configuration variables. These take precedence over any other
configuration variables elsewhere, and are the values passed as
command-line parameters in the "robohydra" executable.

props.name: url
props.description: Request URL

props.name: method
props.description: Request method ("GET", "POST", ...)

props.name: headers
props.description: Request headers

props.name: rawBody
props.description: Request body, if any

params.name: cb
params.description:
Callback to be used when the response is
finished. See the `end` event on the `on` method documentation.

classitems.description:
The currently active scenario, if any. It's an object with the
keys "plugin" and "scenario". If there’s no active scenario,
it’s "\*default\*" / "\*default\*".
classitems.name: currentScenario

classitems.description:
Current scenario/test results. Its keys are plugin names and
its values are objects with scenario names as keys. The values
of the latter objects are test results: objects with the keys
result (value is undefined if the test doesn’t have any result
yet, or pass or fail if at least one assertion has run for that
test), passes (an array with the description of the passing
assertions) and failures (ditto for failing assertions).
classitems.name: scenarioResults

classitems.description: Register the given plugin object at the end of the hydra.
classitems.name: registerPluginObject

props.name: name
props.description:
The name of the plugin. Must
be exclusively comprised of ASCII letters, numbers, underscores
and dashes. Mandatory.

props.name: path
props.description:
The path to the plugin
directory. Mandatory.

props.name: config
props.description:
An object with the
plugin-specific configuration. Optional.

props.name: module
props.description:
The plugin module itself
(ie. an object with the "getBodyParts" function).

classitems.description:
Adds a new (dynamic) head into a hydra. The new head is added
at the beginning of the appropriate pseudo-plugin ("*dynamic*"
by default, "*priority-dynamic*" if the priority is set to
"high"). The order of the plugins is: special admin plugin
(which is normally not visible in the admin interface!),
"*priority-dynamic*", "*dynamic*", "*current-scenario*", and
regular plugins.
classitems.name: registerDynamicHead

params.name: head
params.description: The head to add

params.name: opts
params.description: Options

props.name: priority
props.description:
The priority of the head. Can be
"normal" or "high"

classitems.description: Returns the names of the current plugins, including pseudo-plugins.
classitems.name: getPluginNames

return.description: An array with the names of the plugins in the hydra.

classitems.description: Returns a list of all current plugins, including pseudo-plugins.
classitems.name: getPlugins

return.description: An array containing all plugins in the hydra.

classitems.description: Returns a plugin given its name.
classitems.name: getPlugin

params.name: pluginName
params.description: The name of the plugin

return.description: The plugin with the given name

classitems.description: Returns the first head that matches a given URL.
classitems.name: headForPath

params.name: req
params.description: Request object the head must match

params.name: afterHead
params.description:
If given, only heads after the
given one will be considered for matching.

return.description: First head matching the given URL.

classitems.description: Detach the given head.
classitems.name: detachHead

params.name: pluginName
params.description:
The name of the plugin containing the head to
detach.

params.name: headName
params.description: The name of the head to detach.

classitems.description: Attach the given head.
classitems.name: attachHead

params.name: pluginName
params.description:
The name of the plugin containing the head to
(re-)attach.

params.name: headName
params.description: The name of the head to (re-)attach.

classitems.description: Start the given scenario.
classitems.name: startScenario

params.name: pluginName
params.description:
The name of the plugin containing
the scenario to start.

params.name: scenarioName
params.description: The name of the scenario to start.

classitems.description: Stop the given scenario.
classitems.name: stopScenario

params.name: pluginName
params.description:
The name of the plugin containing
the scenario to stop.

params.name: scenarioName
params.description: The name of the scenario to stop.

classitems.description: Returns an object with the modules for a given plugin.
classitems.name: getModulesObject

params.name: conf
params.description:
The full, resolved configuration for the
plugin the module object is for.

return.description:
Object with the names of the available modules
as keys, and objects with functions as values.

classitems.description:
Creates a RoboHydra server, similar to `http.createServer` or
`https.createServer`. The returned object is in fact the same as
with the `createServer`, so the same methods (`listen`, `on`, etc.)
can be used.
classitems.name: createRoboHydraServer

params.name: config
params.description: Server configuration

props.name: plugins
props.description:
List of plugins to load: each element
in the array must be either a string (name of the plugin to load)
or an object with the keys `name` (string with the plugin name) and
`config` (object with configuration variables for the plugin).

props.name: summoner
props.description:
Summoner configuration. Right now
the only valid key is `hydraPickerPlugin`, the name of the plugin
containing the hydra picker to use (useful in case there are
several).

props.name: pluginLoadPaths
props.description:
Array with extra directories
to search for RoboHydra plugins.

props.name: secure
props.description:
Whether the RoboHydra server should
use HTTPS or not.

props.name: sslOptions
props.description:
SSL options. Only used if
`config.secure` is truthy.

props.name: key
props.description:
The path to the secret key
file for the SSL certificate.

props.name: cert
props.description:
The path to the certificate
file for the SSL certificate.

classitems.description:
Serves a static file with correct headers and such, writing the
result in the given response object.
classitems.name: serveStaticFile

params.name: filePath
params.description: The full path of the file to be served.

params.name: res
params.description: Response object to write the response to.

props.name: fs
props.description:
The 'fs' module (or a mock) to be used
when reading from the filesystem.

props.name: mime
props.description:
The 'mime' module (or a mock) to be
used when figuring out the MIME type for a file.

props.name: headers
props.description:
An object with the incoming
request headers (for caching and such).

props.name: indexFiles
props.description:
An array with the filenames to
be used as index if the given file path is a directory (by
default, "index.html", "index.htm", "home.html" and
"home.htm").

classitems.description:
Proxies the given request to the given URL, writing the result
in the given response object.
classitems.name: proxyRequest

params.name: req
params.description: The request object to proxy.

params.name: res
params.description: The response object to write the result to.

params.name: proxyTo
params.description:
The URL to proxy to, either in the form of
a URL object (result of the url.parse method) or a string.

props.name: httpRequestFunction
props.description:
The http.request
function or a mock of it.

props.name: httpsRequestFunction
props.description:
The https.request
function or a mock of it.

props.name: setHostHeader
props.description:
Specifies if the "Host"
header should be set in the proxied request, so pretend as if
the original request was indeed intended for the final
URL. Defaults to false.

classitems.description:
Request URL path, including GET parameters (eg. `/foo`,
`/bar/qux`, `/articles?order=date`).
classitems.name: url

classitems.description: Request method, normalised to uppercase.
classitems.name: method

classitems.description:
Request headers. Note that the header names are Node-style
(ie. lowercase).
classitems.name: headers

classitems.description:
Request body, if the body was parseable. Otherwise,
`undefined`.
classitems.name: rawBody

classitems.description: Request body parameters.
classitems.name: bodyParams

classitems.description: Request query parameters ("GET" parameters).
classitems.name: queryParams

classitems.description: Request query parameters ("GET" parameters).
classitems.name: getParams

classitems.description:
Request URL path captured parameters. Note that this attribute
is only available in request objects passed directly by
RoboHydra, not in user-created request objects.

When defining URL paths, expressions like `:id` or `:user` can
be used as part of the regular expression (eg. `/save/:id` or
`/:user/preferences`). These expressions will match any URL
path fragment, and the matched contents will be available in
the `params` object in the request object. For example, if you
have a head for path `/articles/:articleid/view` and you
receive a request for
`/articles/introduction-to-robohydra/view`, the request object
will have a `params` property with a single property,
`articleid` with value `introduction-to-robohydra`.
classitems.name: params

classitems.description: Response body.
classitems.name: body

classitems.description: Response status code (by default, `200`).
classitems.name: statusCode

classitems.description:
Response headers. Note that the header names are Node-style
(ie. lowercase).
classitems.name: headers

classitems.description: Whether the response is finished.
classitems.name: ended

classitems.description: Sets and writes the response headers.
classitems.name: writeHead

params.name: statusCode
params.description: The response's status code.

params.name: headers
params.description: The response's headers.

classitems.description:
Appends data to the response body. This method allows a
RoboHydra head to write the response body in chunks, and the
response will be sent in chunks to the client (so you could,
say, send data, then wait, then send more data, wait, then
close the connection).
classitems.name: write

params.name: chunk
params.description:
Data to add to the current response
body. This parameter can be a string, too.

classitems.description:
Appends the given data to the response body and closes
it. Equivalent to calling the `write` method, then `end`.
classitems.name: send

params.name: data
params.description: to add to the response body.

classitems.description:
Marks the response as complete and calls the 'end'
callback. When called in the response object provided by
RoboHydra, this closes the connection.
classitems.name: end

classitems.description:
Copies the response given as a parameter into the current
response object. This is intended to be used when the response
given as a parameter is already finished.
classitems.name: copyFrom

params.name: res
params.description: Response object to copy.

classitems.description:
Forwards the response given as a parameter. That is, copies the
given response in the current object, then marks the given
object as finished.
classitems.name: forward

params.name: res
params.description: The response object to forward.

classitems.description:
Adds a callback to the given event. An event can have more than
one callback. All callbacks for an event will be called in
order when the event is triggered.

The callback function will receive a single parameter, `event`,
an object with the property `type` set to the event type, plus
different properties according to the event fired. It returns
the response object.

The list of response object events is:

* `head`: Fired when the header is written. Event objects for
this event contain two properties, `statusCode` and
`headers`.
* `data`: Fired when there is data written in the response
object. Event objects for this event contain a single property,
`data`, an instance of `Buffer`.
* `end`: Fired when the response is finished. Event objects for
this event contain a single property, `response`, the response
object that fired the event.

For responses you have created yourself to pass to the `next`
function, the `end` event would typically be used to inspect or
modify the response contents, then write data to the response
object you received, possibly with the help of the methods
below.
classitems.name: on

params.name: eventName
params.description:
The name of the event to attach the
callback to. Possible event names are `head`, `data` and `end`.

params.name: cb
params.description: The callback to attach to the given event.

classitems.description:
Follows the given response: as data is written to the given
response object, that same data will be written in the calling
object (ie. it honours and replicates streaming). It's similar
to `copyFrom`, but with the following differences:

* `follow` is to be used _before_ any data is written to the
  source object (ie. the parameter).
* `follow` will write data as it is received, instead of
  everything at once.
classitems.name: chain

params.name: response
params.description:
Response object to chain to the
current object.

classitems.description:
Chains the response given as a parameter to the current
object. This means that as data is written to the current
object, that same data will be written in the parameter (ie. it
honours and replicates streaming). It's similar to `copyFrom`,
but with the following differences:

* `chain` is called on the source object, not the target.
* `chain` is to be used _before_ any data is written to the
  source object.
* `chain` will write data as it's received, instead of
  everything at once.
classitems.name: chain

params.name: response
params.description:
Response object to chain to the
current object.
